body.p: Numerical solution of a nonlinear advance-delay-differential equation from nerve conduction theory
Henjin Chi, Jonathan Bell and Brian Hassard

Abstract. A functional differential equation which is nonlinear and involves forward and backward deviating arguments is solved numerically. The equation models conduction in a myelinated nerve axon in which the myelin completely insulates the membrane, so that the potential change jumps from node to node. The equation is of first order with boundary values given at 𝑡plus-or-minust=±∞t=\pm\infty. The problem is approximated via a difference scheme which solves the problem on a finite interval by utilizing an asymptotic representation at the endpoints, cubic interpolation and iterative techniques to approximate the delays, and a continuation method to start the procedure. The procedure is tested on a class of problems which are solvable analytically to access the scheme’s accuracy and stability, then applied to the problem that models propagation in a myelinated axon. The solution’s dependence on various model parameters of physical interest is studied. This is the first numerical study of myelinated nerve conduction in which the advance and delay terms are treated explicitly.
Key words: Functional differential equation – Advance-delay-diflerential equation – Continuation method – Nerve conduction – Finite difference method – Numerical functional diflerential equation
1. Introduction
In this paper we solve a nonlinear, mixed-delay differential equation defined on the real line. The problem has the form

where 𝑣𝑡v⁢(t)v(t) represents the transmembrane potential at a node in our simplified model for nerve conduction in a myelinated axon. The internodal delay 𝜏τ,\tau, represents the reciprocal of the speed of the potential wave as it propagates down the axon. This constant 𝜏τ\tau is unknown a priori and must be found simultaneously with 𝑣𝑡v⁢(t)v(t) . The constants R and C represent axoplasmic nodal resistivity and nodal capacity, respectively. ~𝐹F~\tilde{F} includes the model current-voltage relation.

In Sect. 2 we give a derivation of the model. In Sects. 3-6 we describe a numerical scheme with local truncation error of order four for solving (1.1). The problem is solved on a finite interval, with asymptotic approximations used outside the interval. The Eq. (1.1) is discretized by using a five point formula for the time derivative terms, and cubic interpolation for the delayed and advanced terms. We use finite difference methods to set up a system of 𝑁2N+2N+2 equations to solve 𝑁2N+2N+2 unknowns. Since the function ~𝐹F~\tilde{F} is nonlinear, the Newton-Raphson iteration procedure was used to approach the solution. Because it is a nonlinear system, we need an initial guess of the solution. Using a test problem, which is solvable analytically, and a continuation method, we obtain the solution of the desired problem by using the exact solution of the test problem to start the continuation method. In Sect. 7 we present numerical results of the method. We test the accuracy of the method on several test problems. Then we apply the method to our specific model. We determine the dependence of the solution 𝑣𝑡v⁢(t)v(t) , and 𝜏τ\tau, on the various parameters b,a,R and C, and interpret the results.
2. Model formulation

Myelination of an axon allows it to conduct neuroelectric signals by exciting only a small percentage of membrane exposed to the extracellular medium at the node of Ranvier (see Fig. 1), particularly in the peripheral nervous system 316. This permits transmission at greatly reduced energy expenditure and higher speeds than comparably sized unmyelinated axons 16.

Because myelin has a higher resistance and lower capacitance than membrane, when the membrane is depolarized at a node, it tends not to depolarize the adjacent region of membrane, but instead it appears to jump to the next node to excite the membrane there 16 (called saltatory conduction). There have been a number of papers associated with mathematical modeling and examining various quantitative relations between model parameters 123121415. Most analytical studies have formulated a mathematical model from an electrical circuit model which assumes what we call the pure saltatory conduction (PSC) hypothesis, namely, the myelin has such high resistance, and low capacitance that it completely insulates the membrane.

In a PSC model all excitable behavior is at the nodes and no transmembrane current is allowed through the internode. Consider the electrical circuit model given by Fig. 2. The superscript𝑟𝑖superscript𝑟𝑜superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑘𝑜superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑘𝑜ri,ro,Vki,Vko,jki,jkor^{i},r^{o},V_{k}^{i},V_{k}^{o},j_{k}^{i},j_{k}^{o} represent, respectively, the longitudinal resistances, longitudinal membrane potentials and currents across the kth node 13. The superscript ”i” (for inner) refers to axoplasmic quantities, the super- script ”o” (for outer) refers to extracellar quantities, and the superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑘𝑚jkmj_{k}^{m} represents membrane current at the 𝑘thk⁢thk\mathrm{t}\mathrm{h} node. Applying Kirchhoff’s and Ohm’s law to the circuit model, we then obtain:
superscript𝑟𝑜superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑘𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑘1𝑜2superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑘𝑜superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑘1𝑜-ro⁢jkm=Vk-1o-2⁢Vko+Vk+1o-r^{o}j_{k}^{m}=V_{k-1}^{o}-2V_{k}^{o}+V_{k+1}^{o}.

Now let 𝑅superscript𝑟𝑖superscript𝑟𝑜R=ri+roR=r^{i}+r^{o}subscript𝑉𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑘𝑜Vk=Vki-VkoV_{k}=V_{k}^{i}-V_{k}^{o}. Then by subtracting (2.1b) from (2.1a), we obtain the following equation at the kth node:
𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑘𝑚subscript𝑉𝑘12subscript𝑉𝑘subscript𝑉𝑘1R⁢jkm=Vk-1-2⁢Vk+Vk+1Rj_{k}^{m}=V_{k-1}-2V_{k}+V_{k+1}.
Now, as in 13, we suppose that the membrane current for the node is the sum of parallel capacity and ionic currents, thus giving
superscriptsubscript𝑗𝑘𝑚𝐶𝑑subscript𝑉𝑘𝑑𝑇𝐼subscript𝑉𝑘jkm=C⁢d⁢Vkd⁢T+I⁢(Vk)j_{k}^{m}=C\frac{dV_{k}}{dT}+I(V_{k}) .
By combining Eqs. (2.2) and (2.3), we obtain the following difference-differential equation model of transmembrane potential subscript𝑉𝑘VkV_{k} at the kth node:
subscript𝑉𝑘12subscript𝑉𝑘subscript𝑉𝑘1𝑅𝐶𝑑subscript𝑉𝑘𝑑𝑇𝐼subscript𝑉𝑘Vk-1-2⁢Vk+Vk+1R=C⁢d⁢Vkd⁢T+I⁢(Vk)\frac{V_{k-1}-2V_{k}+V_{k+1}}{R}=C\frac{dV_{k}}{dT}+I(V_{k}) .

In addition to the PSC hypothesis and the assumption concerning parallel capacity and ionic currents, the circuit model assumes that the axon is infinite in extent, that axon cross-sectional variations in potential (hence current) are negligible and that nodes are point sources of excitation, electrically identical and uniformly spaced.

At this point, various models can be studied depending upon what is chosen for the current-voltage expression 𝐼𝑉I⁢(V)I(V) . 𝐼𝑉I⁢(V)I(V) may also depend upon other ”state variables” satisfying their own voltage-dependent dynamics. For example, using a linear current-voltage relation, Landahl 12 showed there was a critical inter- nodal length and diameter maximizing conduction velocity, while McNeal 14 computed strength-duration curves using a more physiologically realistic I. A more realistic model of the nodal membrane dynamics is one by Frankenhaeuser and Huxley 8, where their current-voltage relation 𝐼𝑉I⁢(V)I(V) is the sum of three ion-specific current densities and a residual current. We choose the well known FitzHugh-Nagumo model 9 at each node since it has been used in studies of unmyelinated axons and has proven to be quite useful in exploring threshold behavior, action potential and repetitive activity. With FitzHugh-Nagumo dynamics for the nodal membrane, without a recovery term, system (2.4) becomes
subscript𝑉𝑘12subscript𝑉𝑘subscript𝑉𝑘1𝑅𝐶𝑑subscript𝑉𝑘𝑑𝑇𝐹subscript𝑉𝑘Vk-1-2⁢Vk+Vk+1R=C⁢d⁢Vkd⁢T-F⁢(Vk)\displaystyle\frac{V_{k-1}-2V_{k}+V_{k+1}}{R}=C\frac{dV_{k}}{dT}-F(V_{k}) .

𝐹𝑉F⁢(V)F(V) is a current-voltage relation that has the nonlinear cubic behavior below: 𝐹superscript𝐶10𝑄F∈C1⁢[0,Q]F\in C^{1}[0,\ Q]; 𝐹0𝐹𝑄0F⁢(0)=F⁢(Q)=0F(0)=F(Q)=0; 𝐹𝑥0F⁢(x)<0F(x)<0 for 0𝑥𝑃0<x<P0<x<P, superscript𝐹′00F′⁢(0)<0F^{\prime}(0)<0;
𝐹𝑥0F⁢(x)>0F(x)>0 for formulae-sequence𝑃𝑥𝑄superscript𝐹′𝑄0P<x<Q,F′⁢(Q)<0P<x<Q,F^{\prime}(Q)<0.

𝑉0V≡0V\equiv 0 represents the rest potential, the threshold potential is represented by 𝑉𝑃V≡P,V\equiv P, and 𝑉𝑄V≡QV\equiv Q represents the fully-activated potential level of the node. Some analytical results for the model wilh recovery are given in Bell 2. Below we concentrate on one representative function satisfying (2.6), namely 𝐹𝑥𝐵𝑥𝑄𝑥𝑥𝑃F⁢(x)=B⁢x⁢(Q-x)⁢(x-P)F(x)=Bx(Q-x)(x-P) . Now assume that a suprathreshold stimulus initiates a propagated action potential which then travels from node to node down the axon. Longitudinal circulating currents are set up which excite successive nodes. Because of the uniformity assumption, each succeeding node responds exactly as its predecessor except for an internodal time delay italic-ϕ0ϕ>0\phi>0; that is
subscript𝑉𝑗1𝑇italic-ϕsubscript𝑉𝑗𝑇Vj+1⁢(T+ϕ)=Vj⁢(T)V_{j+1}(T+\phi)=V_{j}(T) for all 𝑗𝑍j∈Zj\in Z, all T

If l is the internodal length, the speed is given by 𝑣𝑙italic-ϕv=l/ϕv=l/\phi. One object here is to gain an understanding of how italic-ϕϕ\phi (and therefore v) depends on other model parameters. Because of (2.7) we can consider the behavior at a single node, since the behavior at any other node is just a time translation. Letting 𝑉𝑇subscript𝑉𝑘𝑇V⁢(T)=Vk⁢(T)V(T)=V_{k}(T) , then V satisfies
with formulae-sequence𝑉0𝑉𝑄V⁢(-∞)=0,V⁢(+∞)=QV(-\infty)=0,V(+\infty)=Q.

This problem is a nonlinear, mixed-delay, boundary value problem defined on the real line in which italic-ϕϕ\phi is unknown a priori. Before proceeding, we want to reduce parameters by nondimensionalizing (2.8). To nondimensionalize the model, let
𝑡𝑇𝑅𝐶t=TR⁢Ct=\frac{T}{RC}, 𝜏italic-ϕ𝑅𝐶τ=ϕR⁢C\tau=\frac{\phi}{RC}, 𝑣𝑡𝑉𝑇𝑄v⁢(t)=V⁢(T)Qv(t)=\frac{V(T)}{Q}.
With these substitutions, the model becomes
𝑑𝑣𝑡𝑑𝑡𝑓𝑣𝑡𝑣𝑡𝜏2𝑣𝑡𝑣𝑡𝜏d⁢v⁢(t)d⁢t=f⁢(v⁢(t))+v⁢(t-τ)-2⁢v⁢(t)+v⁢(t+τ)\displaystyle\frac{dv(t)}{dt}=f(v(t))+v(t-\tau)-2v(t)+v(t+\tau) ,
with formulae-sequence𝑣0𝑣1v⁢(-∞)=0,v⁢(+∞)=1v(-\infty)=0,v(+\infty)=1, where we obtain
formulae-sequence𝑎𝑃𝑄0𝑎1a=P/Q,0<a<1a=P/Q,0<a<1, and formulae-sequence𝑏⋅𝑅𝐵superscript𝑄2𝑏0b=R⋅B⋅Q2,b>0b=R\cdot B\cdot Q^{2},b>0.
Notice in (2.9), the scaling here is not the usual scaling in a cable model for nonmyelinated axon, but it serves our purpose.

In the nondimensional model, a is the threshold potential, 𝜏τ\tau is the nondimensional time delay, and b is related to the strength of the ionic current density. Since the current-voltage relation is just 𝑓𝑣f⁢(v)f(v) , once a node is “turned on it cannot return to the rest potential 𝑣0v=0v=0. Therefore we expect the behavior of the solution at any node to be monotone increasing, that is, the solution to (2.10)- (2.11) represents a traveling front solution to (2.5)-(2.6).

In this paper the class of problems of interest is
𝑡-∞<t<+∞-\infty<t<+\infty, with 𝑣0v⁢(-∞)=0v(-\infty)=0, 𝑣1v⁢(+∞)=1v(+\infty)=1.

4. The finite difference and interpolation schemes
Consider the following nonlinear mixed-delay problem
formulae-sequence𝑑𝑣𝑡𝑑𝑡𝑓𝑣𝑡𝑣𝑡𝜏2𝑣𝑡𝑣𝑡𝜏𝐿𝑡𝐿d⁢v⁢(t)d⁢t=f⁢(v⁢(t))+v⁢(t-τ)-2⁢v⁢(t)+v⁢(t+τ),-L≤t≤L\displaystyle\frac{dv(t)}{dt}=f(v(t))+v(t-\tau)-2v(t)+v(t+\tau)\ ,\ -L\leq t\leq L,
with the following condition

This equation is defined in a fixed interval, where f is nonlinear and 𝑓0𝑓10f⁢(0)=f⁢(1)=0f(0)=f(1)=0. Since the equation is autonomous, time translates of solutions are also solutions. To fix the phase of the solution, we impose condition (4.2).

We use a fixed, uniform step size ℎhh in this scheme. We divided 𝐿𝐿[-L,L][-L,\ L] into N equal size subintervals, letting formulae-sequencesubscript𝑡𝑗𝐿𝑗ℎ𝑗012⋯𝑁tj=-L+j⁢h,j=0,1,2,⋯,Nt_{j}=-L+jh,j=0,1,2,\cdots,N, where 𝑁2𝐿ℎN=2⁢L/hN=2L/h and approximate 𝑣subscript𝑡𝑗v⁢(tj)v(t_{j}) by subscript𝑣𝑗vjv_{j}. We adopt a fourth-order scheme to approximate the derivative term. From 4, we have
for some 𝜁𝜁𝑡2ℎ𝑡2ℎζ,ζ∈(t-2⁢h,t+2⁢h)\zeta,\zeta\in(t-2h,\ t+2h) .
Thus, we have for the derivative term
superscript𝑣′subscript𝑡𝑗112ℎsubscript𝑣𝑗28subscript𝑣𝑗18subscript𝑣𝑗1subscript𝑣𝑗2v′⁢(tj)=112⁢h⁢(vj-2-8⁢vj-1+8⁢vj+1-vj+2)v^{\prime}(t_{j})=\displaystyle\frac{1}{12h}(v_{j-2}-8v_{j-1}+8v_{j+1}-v_{j+2}) .

For 𝑗0j=0j=0 and 𝑗1j=1j=1, terms subscript𝑣2v-2v_{-2} and subscript𝑣1v-1v_{-1} appear on the right-hand side of (4.3). In these cases, we use the approximate formula (3.14) for 𝑡𝐿2ℎt=-L-2⁢ht=-L-2h and 𝑡𝐿ℎt=-L-ht=-L-h to approximate these terms. Similarly, for 𝑗𝑁1j=N-1j=N-1 and 𝑗𝑁j=Nj=N, terms subscript𝑣𝑁1vN+1v_{N+1} and subscript𝑣𝑁2vN+2v_{N+2} appear on the right-hand side of (4.3). We use (3.19) for 𝑡𝐿ℎt=L+ht=L+h and 𝑡𝐿2ℎt=L+2⁢ht=L+2h to approximate these terms.

To approximate the delayed and the advanced terms in (4.1), we use cubic interpolation. Let 𝑀delimited-[]𝜏ℎM=[τ/h]M=[\tau/h], where delimited-[]𝑥[x][x] means the integer part of x, and let 𝑟𝜏𝑀ℎr=τ-M⁢hr=\tau-Mh; note that 𝑟0r≥0r\geq 0. where the subscript𝐶𝑖CiC_{i}’s are constants, given by
Thus, we have for the delayed term

𝑣subscript𝑡𝑗𝜏subscript𝐶4subscript𝑣𝑗𝑀2subscript𝐶3subscript𝑣𝑗𝑀1subscript𝐶2subscript𝑣𝑗𝑀subscript𝐶1subscript𝑣𝑗𝑀1v⁢(tj-τ)≈C4⁢vj-M-2+C3⁢vj-M-1+C2⁢vj-M+C1⁢vj-M+1v(t_{j}-\tau)\approx C_{4}v_{j-M-2}+C_{3}v_{j-M-1}+C_{2}v_{j-M}+C_{1}v_{j-M+1}.
When terms on the right-hand side of (4.5) have negative indices, formula (3.14) is used to approximate these terms. Similarly, we have for the advanced term

𝑣subscript𝑡𝑖𝜏subscript𝐶4subscript𝑣𝑗𝑀2subscript𝐶3subscript𝑣𝑖𝑀1subscript𝐶2subscript𝑣𝑗𝑀subscript𝐶1subscript𝑣𝑗𝑀1v⁢(ti+τ)≈C4⁢vj+M+2+C3⁢vi+M+1+C2⁢vj+M+C1⁢vj+M-1v(t_{i}+\tau)\approx C_{4}v_{j+M+2}+C_{3}v_{i+M+1}+C_{2}v_{j+M}+C_{1}v_{j+M-1},
and when terms on the right-hand side of (4.6) have indices exceeding N, formula (3.19) is used to approximate these terms.

By using (4.3) to (4.6) to replace the derivative, delayed and advanced terms in the equation (4.1), the approximation scheme has a local truncation error of order four. The discretized version of (4.1) is then

In the system (4.7), the subscript𝑣jvjv_{\mathrm{j}}’s for 𝑗0j<0j<0 are functions of subscript𝑣0v0v_{0}, and are evaluated by using (3.14) with italic-ϵsubscript𝑣0ϵ=v0\epsilon=v_{0}, and neglecting the terms 𝑂superscriptitalic-ϵ4O⁢(ϵ4)O(\epsilon^{4}) . The subscript𝑣𝑗vjv_{j}’s for 𝑗𝑁j>Nj>N are functions of subscript𝑣𝑁vNv_{N}, and are evaluated by using (3.19) with subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript𝑣𝑁ϵ+=1-vN\epsilon_{+}=1-v_{N} and neglecting the terms 𝑂superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ4O⁢(ϵ+4)O(\epsilon_{+}^{4}) .
In addition to the 𝑁1N+1N+1 equations in (4.7), there is the condition
subscript𝑣𝑁0.50vN,-0.5=0v_{N},-0.5=0, where superscript𝑁′delimited-[]𝑁2N′=[N/2]N^{\prime}=[N/2]
which replaces (4.2), and in addition to the 𝑁1N+1N+1 unknowns subscript𝑣0subscript𝑣1⋯subscript𝑣𝑁v0,v1,⋯,vNv_{0},v_{1},\cdots,v_{N} there is the unknown delay 𝜏τ.\tau.
5. Solution of the discretized system

There are many possible ways of solving the system (4.7), (4.8) for subscript𝑣0subscript𝑣1v0,v1v_{0},v_{1}, . . . , subscript𝑣𝑁vN,v_{N}, and 𝜏τ\tau. If the Newton-Raphson scheme were used directly, the approximate 𝜏τ\tau would vary in each iteration step, and the coefficient matrix might vary in bandwidth because the integer 𝑀MM and the coefficients formulae-sequencesubscript𝐶𝑘𝑘1⋯4Ck,k=1,⋯,4C_{k},k=1,\cdots,4 depend upon 𝜏τ\tau. To avoid the potential for discontinuous change in 𝑀MM and the subscript𝐶𝑘CkC_{k}’s during the iteration, we designed a nested iteration scheme in which 𝜏τ\tau is fixed during the inner loop. The outer loop is the solution of an equation 𝑔𝜏0g⁢(τ)=0g(\tau)=0 by the secant method, where the function 𝑔𝜏g⁢(τ)g(\tau) is defined as follows:
Definition of𝑔𝜏g⁢(τ)g(\tau) . For fixed 𝜏τ\tau, we solve the system of 𝑁1N+1N+1 equations
for 𝑗01⋯superscript𝑁′1j=0,1,⋯,N′-1j=0,1,\cdots,N^{\prime}-1
for 𝑗superscript𝑁′1⋯𝑁j=N′+1,⋯,Nj=N^{\prime}+1,\cdots,N
for subscript𝑣0subscript𝑣1⋯subscript𝑣𝑁v0,v1,⋯,vNv_{0},v_{1},\cdots,v_{N}. Then, we define 𝑔𝜏absentg⁢(τ)=g(\tau)=left- hand side of (4.7) for 𝑗superscript𝑁′j=N′.j=N^{\prime}.

This particular definition of 𝑔𝜏g⁢(τ)g(\tau) was arrived at after a certain amount of numerical experimentation. Unsuccessful attempts were made to solve the system (4.7) directly, and we tried to solve a modified version of (4.7) with the first equation replaced by a phase-fixing condition subscript𝑣0absentv0=v_{0}=constant which was found to be ineffective. The system (5.1) applies the phase-fixing condition to the component subscript𝑣superscript𝑁𝑟vNrv_{N^{r}} where it was found to be effective. Note that replacing the Eq. (5.1) for 𝑗superscript𝑁′j=N′j=N^{\prime} with the equation subscript𝑣superscript𝑁′0.50vN′-0.5=0v_{N^{\prime}}-0.5=0 preserves the band structure of the Jacobian matrix.

To approximate a solution to this nonlinear system (5.1), we use the Newton- Raphson scheme 5. Given the initial approximation superscript𝑉0V0V^{0}, a sequence of iterates formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑉𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑣0𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑣1𝑘…superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑁𝑘𝑘0 1⋯{Vk=(v0k,v1k,…,vNk),k=0, 1,⋯}\{V^{k}=\ (v_{0}^{k},\ v_{1}^{k},\ \ldots\ ,\ v_{N}^{k}),\ k=0,\ 1,\cdots\} is generated. This sequence converges to the solution provided that the superscript𝑉0V0V^{0} is sufficiently close to the solution and the Jacobian matrix, J, is nonsingular at the solution.

The Jacobian matrix for the system (5.1) is a banded matrix with band width 2𝑀52⁢M+52M+5. In the numerical scheme, the Jacobian matrix was approximated by one-sided numerical differencing. The known band structure of the matrix was used to minimize the number of function evaluations required, and a banded matrix solver LEQT2B from the IMSL9 10 was used to solve the linear systems at each stage in the Newton-Raphson iteration.
ff\mathrm{f}. Continuation method
In the class of problems (3.1) we are considering, we have a test problem which we can solve exactly. This is (3.1) with the following expression for f:

. The solution to (3.1), (6.1) is formulae-sequence𝑣𝑡1𝑡2𝑡𝑅v⁢(t)=(1+tanh⁡(t))/2,t∈Rv(t)=(1+\tanh(t))/2,t\in R, and 𝜏superscript1italic-ϑτ=tanh-1⁡(ϑ)\tau=\tanh^{-1}(\sqrt{\vartheta}) . We may use this information and the continuation method (see 719) to solve other problems within our class of problems. Because we are solving a large system of nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method, it is very difficult to determine the initial guess which is close to the solution. So we take advantage of the test problem and continuation method to approach the solution we want. The way we use the continuation method on our class of problems is as follows. Consider the problem (3.1) with any nonlinearity subscript𝑓𝑑𝑣fd⁢(v)f_{d}(v) in our general class of f’s which represents our target problem for which we desire the solution. We embed this problem in a one-parameter family of problems
with formulae-sequence𝑣0𝑣1v⁢(-∞)=0,v⁢(∞)=1v(-\infty)=0,v(\infty)=1,
with subscript𝑓italic-ϑ𝑣fϑ⁢(v)f_{\vartheta}(v) given by (6.1).

We compute solutions for 𝛼α\alpha varying from 𝛼1α=1\alpha=1 to 𝛼0α=0\alpha=0. For 𝛼1α=1\alpha=1, we are just solving the test problem for which the exact 𝑣𝑡v⁢(t)v(t) and 𝜏τ\tau are known. This exact solution is used as the initial guess to solve the correspond discrete system (4.7). Once a problem for 𝛼0α>0\alpha>0 is solved, we decrease 𝛼α\alpha incrementally by Δ𝛼Δ⁢α\Delta\alpha and use the solution to previous problem as the initial approximation to obtain the solution to the current problem. When we have solved the problem for 𝛼0α=0,\alpha=0, we are done.
We solved the problem (2.10) numerically by the scheme presented above on the CDC Cyber 815. We shall discuss the results in the next section.
7. Numerical results

In this section we present results of numerically solving (3.1) using a FORTRAN program which employs the method outlined in Sects. 3-6. To start with, we determine the accuracy of the method by applying our scheme to the test problem (6.1) with known solution. Then, we feed the continuation method with two different test problems from (6.1), whose solutions are also known so that we are sure of the accuracy of the continuation method. Having verified the convergence of our scheme with the continuation method, we solve our target problem (2.11), starting the continuation method from one test problem of the form (6.1). It is worth noting that we started the continuation method from three different test problems and for each case we approached to the target problem (2.11) and got the same solution. Then we consider the effects of parameter changes on the solution, and delay 𝜏τ\tau, of the Eq. (2.8) and (2.10).
Consider the following problem:
𝑡-∞<t<+∞-\infty<t<+\infty with formulae-sequence𝑣0𝑣1v⁢(-∞)=0,v⁢(+∞)=1v(-\infty)=0,v(+\infty)=1,

where subscript𝑓italic-ϑfϑf_{\vartheta} is given by (6.1). This will be referred to as our test problem since, as we mentioned above, we know the solution and delay 𝜏τ\tau a priori. We use the scheme described above. We pick up a italic-ϑ131ϑ∈(1/3,1)\vartheta\in(1/3,1) and replace the coefficients in Sect. 3 by their actual values. Choosing our test problem with italic-ϑ0.35ϑ=0.35\vartheta=0.35, we have, analytically, the delay subscript𝜏𝑒𝑥𝑎𝑐𝑡0.680136τe⁢x⁢a⁢c⁢t=0.680136\tau_{exact}=0.680136. For this problem we ran the program with formulae-sequenceℎ0.1formulae-sequence𝑁41formulae-sequenceitalic-ϵ0.001𝜃0.35h=0.1,N=41,ϵ=0.001,θ=0.35h=0.1,N=41,\epsilon=0.001,\theta=0.35, and 𝐿2.0L=2.0L=2.0. Since the system is nonlinear, we provide the initial guess of the solution to the iteration procedure by furnishing the program 𝑁41N=41N=41 mesh point values which came from the exact solution. Additionally, we need to find out 𝜏τ\tau by the secant method. Given subscript𝜏1subscript𝜏𝑒𝑥𝑎𝑐𝑡0.001τ1=τe⁢x⁢a⁢c⁢t+0.001\tau_{1}=\tau_{exact}+0.001 and subscript𝜏2subscript𝜏𝑒𝑥𝑎𝑐𝑡0.001τ2=τe⁢x⁢a⁢c⁢t-0.001\tau_{2}=\tau_{exact}-0.001, the program proceeds to iterate until the norm in the inner loop was less than superscript101010-1010^{-10} and the norm of 𝜏τ\tau in the outer loop is less than superscript10810-8.10^{-8}. As the result, we obtained the solution, presented in Table 1, of the delay equation and 𝜏0.6801398τ=0.6801398\tau=0.6801398 with the error between computed and exact delay being 3.5superscript1063.5×10-63.5\times 10^{-6}. To check the accuracy and the stability of our scheme, we reduced h by one half, reran the program, and obtained 𝜏0.6801364τ=0.6801364\tau=0.6801364, with the error being 1.6superscript1071.6×10-71.6\times 10^{-7}. The solution of the second experiment and the exact solution are also included in Table 1 for comparison. Notice that we obtained the initial guess for 𝑁81N=81N=81 case by applying the cubic interpolation method to the solutions of 𝑁41N=41N=41 case. From Table 1, we conclude that the computed solution agrees with the exact solution to better than five digits. Moreover, since the difference between computed results of 𝑁41N=41N=41 and 𝑁81N=81N=81 is 𝑂superscript106O⁢(10-6)O(10^{-6}) which is within the error tolerance Osuperscript104O⁢(10-4)\mathrm{O}(10^{-4}) , we proceeded to use 𝑁41N=41N=41 in the rest of the calculations. We now test the numerical scheme in conjunction with the continuation method by applying it to (7.1) and (6.1) with 𝜃0.35θ=0.35\theta=0.35 for the initial test problem, and 𝜃0.45θ=0.45\theta=0.45 for the problem to be solved. We set 𝛼1α=1\alpha=1 at the beginning, use the exact solution as initial guess for the problem, and choose a pair of numbers as the initial guesses of 𝜏τ\tau. The system is very sensitive and choosing too inaccurate a choice of inital guess of 𝜏τ\tau will cause the divergence of the solution. In the program run we set formulae-sequence𝑁51formulae-sequence𝑎0.05formulae-sequence𝑏15.0ℎ0.2N=51,a=0.05,b=15.0,h=0.2N=51,a=0.05,b=15.0,h=0.2, and 𝐿5.0L=5.0L=5.0. For each run, once we obtain the solution and 𝜏τ\tau of the delay equation, we decreased 𝛼α\alpha by 0.1 and executed the iteration again. The same procedure was repeated until 𝛼0α=0.\alpha=0. The solution and 𝜏τ\tau obtained are given in Table 2. Comparison of the computed solution and the exact solution is given in Table 3. We ran the same experiment over, starting with different test problems to see how sensitive the continuation method was to changes in the test problem. The initial test problem we adopted was (7.1) with italic-ϑ0.4ϑ=0.4\vartheta=0.4. As predicted, it converged to the same 𝜏0.81229647τ=0.81229647\tau=0.81229647 and we got the solution to agree with that of case 𝜃0.35θ=0.35\theta=0.35 to better than 12 digits. In addition, from Table 3 we realize that the largest error is 0.94superscript1040.94×10-40.94\times 10^{-4}. Therefore, we determined that the continuation method is accurate and in our experiment no matter which initial test problem we start with, we obtained the correct solution. We then applied our numerical approach to the problem (2.10) with 𝑓𝑣f⁢(v)f(v) presented in Sect. 2. The test problem employed is (6.1) with italic-ϑ0.35ϑ=0.35\vartheta=0.35. Running the program with formulae-sequence𝑎0.05formulae-sequence𝑏15formulae-sequenceℎ0.05𝑁41a=0.05,b=15,h=0.05,N=41a=0.05,b=15,h=0.05,N=41, and 𝐿1L=1L=1, we obtained 𝜏0.4351126τ=0.4351126\tau=0.4351126 and the solution, presented in Table 4, to the problem (2.10). Then we reran our program with italic-ϑ0.40ϑ=0.40\vartheta=0.40 and 0.425 respectively in (6.1). Comparing the results obtained from using different 𝜃θ\theta’s, we realized that for all the test problems we chose, we got the same 𝜏τ\tau, and the approximate solutions computed by the method starting from different test problems agree with each other to better than 12 digits (by using a good matrix solver, LEQT2B in IMSL9, with accuracy of 12 digits). The 𝛼𝜏α-τ\alpha-\tau relation graph for different 𝜃θ\theta’s is exhibited in Fig. 3. The solution to (2.10) for 𝜃0.40θ=0.40\theta=0.40 and 0.425 is included in Table 4 as well. To present the continuation procedure more clearly, the solution changes for different 𝛼α\alpha’s are shown in Fig. 4. The curves in [-2, 2] represent the graph for 𝛼1α=1\alpha=1, 0.8, 0.6, 0.4, 0.2, 0.1 where 𝛼1α=1\alpha=1 is the initial test problem and 𝛼0α=0\alpha=0 is the target problem. Notice that the curves shrink and become more and more stiff as 𝛼α\alpha decreases. Owing to the autonomous nature of this system, the program fixes the function value at 𝑡0t=0t=0, namely, 𝑣00.5v⁢(0)=0.5v(0)=0.5. According to the test results, we are convinced that in all cases the method will reliably give rise to solutions converging to the desired solution of (2.10).

Parameter changes will affect the behavior of the delay 𝜏τ\tau and the solution to the delay equation (2.10). Now we introduce some experiments of changing parameters a,b,R and 𝐶CC and see what happens to the delay 𝜏τ\tau and equation solution. We will explain the behavior changes from the physiological point of view as well. We first examined how changes in the value of the threshold potential affected the rise time and the conduction speed of action potential. We fixed all other parameters by letting formulae-sequenceℎ0.05formulae-sequence𝑁41𝑏15h=0.05,N=41,b=15h=0.05,N=41,b=15, and 𝐿1L=1L=1, and allowed the variable a to vary from 0.01 to 0.12 with increments of 0.01. As a decreases, the solution 𝑣𝑡v⁢(t)v(t) becomes steeper in the middle and flatter on the ends. The change is shown in Fig. 5. This means the rise time of the membrane potential is faster for lower threshold potential. We cannot directly compare this behavior to experimental observations because it is difficult experimentally to determine a precise value for threshold potential in real nodal membrane. Next consider the effect of threshold changes on the behavior of the conduction speed. From Table 5, we observe that the larger is, the larger 𝜏τ\tau is. That is, all other parameters being fixed, an axon with higher threshold potential has lower conduction speed since the conduction speed is inversely proportional to internodal delay 𝜏τ\tau. Hence, axons with higher threshold potential have lower conduction speeds and slower rise times. This gives indirect consistent behavior to some experimental findings of Paintal 17 and Coppin and Jack (unpublished observations, see Jack et al. 11), who found that action potentials (in myelinated fibers of cats) with slower conduction speeds have slower rise times. Since the model dynamics at the nodes is so simplified, we can make only qualitative comparisons with experiments, not quantitative ones.

Next we study the relationship between the strength of ionic current density, 𝑏bb, to the conduction speed and rise time of the membrane potential. We fix formulae-sequenceℎ0.05formulae-sequence𝑁41𝑎0.05h=0.05,N=41,a=0.05h=0.05,N=41,a=0.05, and 𝐿1.0L=1.0L=1.0, and let 𝑏bb vary from 10 to 20 in unit increments. We notice that the smaller b is, the slower the solution rises (see Fig. 6). More specifically, if the strength of the ionic current density is lessened, the rise time of the membrane potential is slower, and 𝜏τ\tau is larger. Hence the conduction speed is larger when the strength of ionic current density is larger. Roughly interpreted, increasing the membrane conductance increases the conduction speed. We do not have experiments on myelinated axons to compare to this result directly, but it is known in studies on unmyelinated axons that increasing membrane conductances, for example imposing a higher density of sodium channels, lead to higher conduction speeds. Therefore all qualitative results seem to be consistent with experimental evidence as far as we can determine.
In the following, we study the behavior of the delay 𝜏τ\tau and the solution to (2.9) under the control of axoplasmic nodal resistance 𝑅RR and modal capacitance C, where the model equation becomes

To determine qualitatively the relationship between the nodal capacitance, C, to the conduction speed and rise time of the membrane potential, we fixed the nodal resistance 𝑅RR equal to 1 and let 𝐶CC vary from 0.7 to 1.3 in increments of 0.1. As seen in Fig. 7, the smaller 𝐶CC is, the faster the solution rises. This means that the rise time of the membrane potential is faster for lower nodal capacitance. From Table 6, we observe that when 𝐶CC increases 𝜏τ\tau increases. That is, if all other parameters are fixed, an axon with higher nodal capacitance has slower conduction speed. This is consistent with our intuition and known results on unmyelinated fibers that increasing the membrane capacitance tends to decrease conduction velocity. This result has also been verified by Moore et al. 15, who numerically examined the sensitivity of propagation speed on nodal capacity (see his Fig. 2). In their paper, they modelled the myelinated axon basically like an unmyelinated axon with spatially varying coefficients. Specifically, they allowed current leakage across the internodal regions, but this does not affect the qualitative dependence of conduction speed on nodal capacitance. It will, of course, have a significant quantitative eflect. The above two observations of our model are also consistent with the previous observation that slower speed wave fronts have slow rise times. Now consider the same model with the nodal capacity 𝐶CC fixed and resistivity R allowed to vary. For convenience we let 𝐶1C=1C=1 and varied R between 0.5 and 2.5. The numerical tests show us that when R decreases, the rise time of the solution decreases (see Fig. 8). In other words, the rise time of the membrane potential is faster for smaller nodal resistance. Again we observe from Table 6 that as 𝑅RR increases, so does 𝜏τ\tau. Hence we conclude that the higher nodal resistance will give rise to slower conduction speed and slower rise time in the action potential. Again this is consistent with the numerical results of Moore et al. 15, as well as previous work on unmyelinated axon modeling.

In summary, we have studied an extremely simple model of nerve conduction for myelinated axons and have found the parameter dependence results consistent with those of previous models and experiments. Of greater interest is our demonstration that the advance and delay terms which arise as a consequence of the traveling wave hypothesis in a saltatory model of myelinated nerve fiber can be treated explicitly, without considering other diffusion approximations. Because the myelinated membranes do allow some transmembrane current to leak across, we have modified the above model to account for this current, and in particular, to consider the effect of myelin resistivity and capacitance. This work will be reported elsewhere.
